Literature Review: Neutrino physics has been a subject of intense research in recent decades, with particular interest in high-energy to ultrahigh-energy neutrino interactions. This review focuses on neutrino interactions at energies above 1 TeV, exploring the current understanding, experimental measurements, and future prospects in this field.Neutrinos are elementary particles that interact weakly with matter, making them challenging to detect but also valuable probes of astrophysical phenomena and fundamental physics. The study of high-energy neutrino interactions is crucial for understanding cosmic ray origins, exploring physics beyond the Standard Model, and probing the extreme universe.The theoretical framework for neutrino interactions at high energies is based on the Standard Model of particle physics. At energies above 1 TeV, neutrino-nucleon interactions are dominated by deep inelastic scattering (DIS), where the neutrino interacts with individual quarks within the nucleon [1]. The cross-section for these interactions increases with energy, approximately linearly up to about 10^5 GeV, after which the growth slows due to electroweak radiative corrections and other effects [2].Experimental measurements of high-energy neutrino cross-sections have been challenging due to the rarity of such interactions and the difficulty in producing high-energy neutrino beams. However, significant progress has been made in recent years. The IceCube Neutrino Observatory, a cubic-kilometer neutrino detector installed in the Antarctic ice, has provided valuable data on high-energy neutrino interactions [3]. By analyzing the zenith-angle and energy dependence of neutrino events, IceCube has measured the neutrino-nucleon cross-section at energies up to about 1 PeV (10^6 GeV) [4].These measurements have generally confirmed theoretical predictions based on the Standard Model, but there is still room for new physics at higher energies. Some theories predict additional contributions to the neutrino cross-section at ultrahigh energies, such as from microscopic black hole production in models with large extra dimensions [5].In addition to IceCube, other experiments have contributed to our understanding of high-energy neutrino interactions. The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN produces a significant flux of high-energy neutrinos as a byproduct of particle collisions. Dedicated experiments like FASERùúà have been designed to detect these neutrinos and measure their interactions [6]. These measurements complement those from cosmic neutrinos, as they probe a different energy range and provide better control over systematic uncertainties.Atmospheric neutrinos, produced by cosmic ray interactions in the Earth's atmosphere, also provide a natural source of high-energy neutrinos. Measurements of the atmospheric neutrino flux extend up to energies of about 400 TeV and have been used to study neutrino oscillations and interactions [7].The detection of astrophysical neutrinos by IceCube in 2013 opened a new window on the high-energy universe [8]. These neutrinos, with energies up to several PeV, are believed to originate from extreme cosmic accelerators such as active galactic nuclei, gamma-ray bursts, or other as-yet-unknown sources. The study of these astrophysical neutrinos not only provides information about their sources but also allows us to probe neutrino physics at the highest energies.Looking to the future, several new experiments and upgrades are planned to extend our knowledge of high-energy neutrino interactions. IceCube-Gen2, a proposed expansion of the IceCube detector, would increase the instrumented volume by an order of magnitude, allowing for better statistics at the highest energies [9]. Radio detection techniques, such as those employed by the ARIANNA and ARA experiments, offer the potential to detect neutrinos at even higher energies, potentially up to 10^20 eV [10].In conclusion, the study of high-energy to ultrahigh-energy neutrino interactions is a rapidly evolving field at the intersection of particle physics, astrophysics, and cosmology. While significant progress has been made in recent years, many questions remain unanswered. Future experiments and theoretical developments promise to shed light on the nature of neutrino interactions at the highest energies, potentially revealing new physics and providing insights into the most energetic phenomena in the universe.
